summary: An annotation-definition creates a new annotation-type in the enclosing package.
details: Object is the direct super of the new type.
Annotation is a direct superinterface of the new type.
The RetentionPolicy of the new type is runtime.
The new type does not directly define any fields, constructors, or methods.
static-checks: Each annotation in an annotation-list must be uniquely typed.
No two types can share the same descriptor.
example-1: module Main in examples;%0A%0Aannotation Alien;%0A%0A@Alien%0A@Start%0Adefun main (args : String[]) : void%0A{%0A    val owner = (class Main);%0A    val name = %22main%22;%0A    val params = [ (class String[]) ];%0A%0A    val func = Reflect::getMethod(owner, name, params);%0A%0A    val applied = func.isAnnotationPresent((class Alien));%0A%0A    F::println(%22@Alien Present = %22 .. applied);%0A}
example-2: module Main in examples;%0A%0Aimport java.lang.reflect.Modifier;%0A%0Aannotation Alien;%0A%0A@Start%0Adefun main (args : String[]) : void%0A{%0A    val klass = (class Alien);%0A%0A    val modifiers = Modifier::toStringklass().getModifiers();%0A%0A    F::println(%22Name = %22 .. klass.getName());%0A%0A    F::println(%22Annotation? = %22 .. klass.isAnnotation());%0A%0A    F::println(%22Modifiers = %22 .. modifiers);%0A}
